original_data.question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of recurrent skin lesions. The episodes of lesions started at the age of 2 months and multiple treatment options have been attempted without success. He has also had several episodes of respiratory tract infections, enlarged lymph nodes, and recurrent fevers since birth. The boy attends daycare. His older brother has asthma. The patient's immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 5th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. He appears ill. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Examination shows several raised, erythematous lesions of different sizes over the face, neck, groins, and extremities; some secrete pus. Cervical and axillary lymph nodes are enlarged bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

model_response:
Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is a disorder of phagocytes. Patients are prone to recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms (e.g., S. aureus). The lymph nodes in CGD are often enlarged, and granulomas may be seen. The classic form of CGD is X-linked; the gene for NADPH oxidase in neutrophils and macrophages is mutated. The result is that these cells cannot produce reactive oxygen species. The other choices do not include a defect in phagocytic cells.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked disease characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and a marked vulnerability to recurrent infection, particularly of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. Patients have reduced IgM levels and increased IgA and IgE levels. There is a defect in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein, which links several membrane receptors to the cytoskeleton.

Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin disease that usually begins in infancy or childhood. It is characterized by itching, inflammation, and crusting of the skin. Patients with atopic dermatitis have an increased incidence of asthma and allergic rhinitis. The cause of atopic dermatitis is unknown, but both genetic and environmental factors play a role.

Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and peripheral neuropathy. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the LYST gene, which encodes a protein involved in lysosomal trafficking.

Sturge-Weber syndrome is characterized by a facial port-wine stain, usually in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve, and angiomatous engorgement of the cerebral cortex. Seizures and mental retardation are common. The cause is a mutation in the GNAQ gene on chromosome 3.

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of factor VIII. Hemophilia A is characterized by a prolonged PTT and a normal PT. Patients with hemophilia A are prone to bleeding, particularly in joints and muscle.

Giuffre G, Rodeghiero F. Primary immune deficiency diseases: an update. Curr Opin Pediatr. 2012 Nov; 24(6):725-31.

### answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.

Applied to a sign, symptom, or other manifestation that occurs multiple times at usually irregular intervals. The occurences are separated by an interval in which the sign, symptom, or manifestation is not present. []
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of skin.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
How long something has existed; elapsed time since birth.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
An indefinite large quantity that is considered to be greater than several.
An event that accomplishes its intended purpose.
A noteworthy happening that is distinctive in a series of related events.
Invasion of the host RESPIRATORY SYSTEM by microorganisms, usually leading to pathological processes or diseases.
The presence of an enlarged lymph node.

An acute infection characterized by recurrent episodes of PYREXIA alternating with asymptomatic intervals of apparent recovery. This condition is caused by SPIROCHETES of the genus BORRELIA. It is transmitted by the BITES of either the body louse (PEDICULUS humanus corporis), for which humans are the reservoir, or by soft ticks of the genus ORNITHODOROS, for which rodents and other animals are the principal reservoirs.
The process of giving birth to one or more offspring.

A form of bronchial disorder with three distinct components: airway hyper-responsiveness (RESPIRATORY HYPERSENSITIVITY), airway INFLAMMATION, and intermittent AIRWAY OBSTRUCTION. It is characterized by spasmodic contraction of airway smooth muscle, WHEEZING, and dyspnea (DYSPNEA, PAROXYSMAL).

Deliberate stimulation of the host's immune response. ACTIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of ANTIGENS or IMMUNOLOGIC ADJUVANTS. PASSIVE IMMUNIZATION involves administration of IMMUNE SERA or LYMPHOCYTES or their extracts (e.g., transfer factor, immune RNA) or transplantation of immunocompetent cell producing tissue (thymus or bone marrow).
Any of the 99 numbered points that divide an ordered set of scores into 100 parts each of which contains one-hundredth of the total.
The linear extent in space from one end of something to the other end, or the extent of something from beginning to end.
The mass or quantity of heaviness of an individual. It is expressed by units of pounds or kilograms.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
The physical magnitude of something.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
The external junctural region between the lower part of the abdomen and the thigh.
The farthest or outermost projections of the body, such as the HAND and FOOT.
The controlled release of a substance by a cell or a tissue. [GOC:ai]
A yellowish substance produced during bacterial inflammation. It contains necrotic cells and cells fighting the infection.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
One of approximately 20-30 lymph nodes in chain formation that traverse the concavity of the underarm to the clavicle.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
